title: Stand-up Comedian Kunal Kamra Casts Doubt on Ola Electric's Customer Complaint Resolution Claims
news:
Stand-up comedian Kunal Kamra has raised skepticism about Ola Electric's recent claim of resolving 99.1% of customer complaints.  This follows the company's response to a Show Cause Notice from the Central Consumer Protection Authority (CCPA) regarding alleged misleading advertisements and unfair trade practices.  Kamra's tweet questioned the company's claim, suggesting that the high resolution rate doesn't reflect the reality of customer experiences.  

Kamra's criticism comes amidst ongoing public scrutiny of Ola Electric's after-sales service and repair delays. The company's stock price fell by 6% following the CCPA's notice.  While Ola Electric maintains a "robust mechanism" for handling complaints,  Kamra's continued criticism highlights the public's ongoing concerns.  The CCPA will verify Ola's claims, but the debate on social media highlights the challenge for Ola Electric to regain customer trust.

title: Cyclone Dana Intensifies, Threatens Odisha and West Bengal Coasts
news:
A deep depression over the Bay of Bengal has intensified into a cyclonic storm named Dana, posing a threat to the coasts of Odisha and West Bengal. The storm is expected to make landfall as a severe cyclonic storm between October 24th and 25th, bringing with it wind speeds of 100-110 km per hour and gusts up to 120 km per hour. 

The India Meteorological Department (IMD) issued a bulletin stating that the storm is likely to intensify further into a severe cyclonic storm by the early morning of October 24th. Coastal districts of Odisha, including Jagatsinghpur, Kendrapara, Bhadrak, and Balasore, are expected to experience the strongest winds, reaching up to 100-110 kmph.  

Heavy rainfall is predicted for the region during October 24th and 25th.  Odisha and West Bengal have mobilized disaster response forces, including the Odisha Disaster Rapid Action Force (ODRAF), fire services teams, and National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) units, to prepare for the storm's impact.

title: Anil Ambani Enters Defense Sector, Outpacing Mukesh Ambani
news: Anil Ambani's Reliance Infrastructure (R-Infra) is making a bold move into the defense sector, a domain his brother, Mukesh Ambani, has not ventured into. R-Infra announced plans to invest Rs 10,000 crore over the next ten years to build India's largest integrated project in Ratnagiri, Maharashtra, for the manufacturing of explosives, ammunition, and small arms. This ambitious venture, dubbed "Dhirubhai Ambani Defence City (DADC)," will span 1,000 acres and involve joint ventures with six global defense giants. The project aims to manufacture a wide range of ammunition, including terminally guided munitions, and cater to both civilian and military markets, including export opportunities. While the names of the joint venture partners have not been disclosed, R-Infra's existing subsidiaries, Jai Armaments Ltd and Reliance Defence Ltd, already hold licenses for arms and ammunition production. This ambitious venture positions R-Infra as a major player in India's burgeoning defense manufacturing landscape.

title: Delhi's Air Quality Remains 'Very Poor' as GRAP Stage 2 Restrictions Take Effect
news:
Delhi's air quality continues to be in the 'very poor' category, with the Air Quality Index (AQI) reaching 349 on Wednesday morning. This grim situation prompted authorities to implement Stage 2 of the Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP) on Tuesday. 

GRAP Stage 2 imposes restrictions including:

* **Ban on coal and firewood:** Use in hotels, restaurants, and open eateries is prohibited.
* **Ban on diesel generator sets:** Use is restricted to emergencies and essential services.

These measures are aimed at mitigating the worsening air pollution in Delhi, which is particularly bad during the winter months due to factors like stubble burning and seasonal changes.  

The Jahangirpuri area was the worst affected with an AQI of 417, while Anand Vihar recorded an AQI of 402. Multiple areas in the city also experienced 'very poor' air quality. 

The situation remains critical and calls for immediate action to curb air pollution in the national capital.

title: Goldman Sachs Downgrades Indian Market, Citing Earnings Concerns
news:
Goldman Sachs has downgraded its stance on the Indian market from overweight to neutral, citing concerns about slower economic growth and corporate profits. The brokerage predicts a potential market correction in the next 3 to 6 months. 

This move follows a weak start to the earnings season, marked by a worsening earnings sentiment and an accelerating pace of earnings cuts.  Goldman Sachs highlights that these factors "signal a flow-through to corporate earnings," suggesting a continued decline in corporate profits. 

The brokerage also notes that high valuations and a less supportive market backdrop will likely limit near-term upside potential. Goldman Sachs has revised its 12-month target for the Nifty index to 27,000, down from the previous target of 27,500.

This downgrade comes on the heels of a similar move by Bernstein Research, which also downgraded the Indian market to "underweight" due to record high valuations, crowding risk, and increasing downgrades.

title: Early Voting Surges in US Presidential Election
news:
With just two weeks until the US presidential election on November 5th, over 21 million Americans have already cast their ballots. This early voting surge reflects the intense campaign between Vice President Kamala Harris (Democrat) and former President Donald Trump (Republican). 

Data from the University of Florida's Election Lab shows 7.8 million votes cast through early in-person voting, while over 13.3 million have been submitted via mail-in ballots.  

While early voting is a unique feature of the US election system,  it is gaining popularity. Notably, Republicans are showing a stronger early voting presence than expected, potentially shifting the electoral landscape. 

Analysts are closely watching the results in seven key battleground states: Arizona, Nevada, Wisconsin, Michigan, Pennsylvania, North Carolina, and Georgia, where the outcome of the election is expected to be decided.

title: New Zealand Batsman Chad Bowes Smashes Fastest List A Double Century
news:
New Zealand batsman Chad Bowes has rewritten the record books, smashing the fastest ever double century in List A one-day cricket. Bowes achieved this feat in a remarkable display against the Otago Volts in the Ford Trophy, scoring 200 runs off just 103 balls. This surpasses the previous record held by Australian batsman Travis Head, who scored 200 off 114 balls, and Chennai Super Kings batsman Narayan Jagadeesan, who also achieved the feat in 114 balls.

Bowes' blistering innings included 7 sixes and 27 fours, showcasing his aggressive approach against both pace and spin bowling. He fell leg-before to Matt Bacon for 205, having scored a staggering 78% of his team's total at the time.

The 32-year-old, who has represented the Black Caps in six ODIs and 11 T20s, has had a remarkable journey.  Having started his career in South Africa, he moved to Canterbury and even captained the South Africa U19 team in the 2012 World Cup, the same tournament in which Travis Head represented Australia. Former Chennai Super Kings head coach Stephen Fleming played a key role in Bowes' career, helping him join the Sydenham Cricket Club in Christchurch. 

Bowes' incredible performance not only broke a world record but also stands as the second-highest individual score in the Ford Trophy, just short of the record 222 set by former Black Caps batsman Jamie How in 2013.

title: From Child Prodigy to Tech Entrepreneur: Ankit Prasad's Journey

In 2012, Prasad launched "Touchtalent", an online platform for art and design enthusiasts.  This venture paved the way for his most successful endeavor, Bobble AI.  

Bobble AI, known for its popular Bobble Indic Keyboard, revolutionized mobile communication by introducing personalized stickers, GIFs, and emojis generated from user selfies.  The app's innovative approach resonated with users, garnering over 15 million downloads and attracting investments from angel investors and SAIF Partners.  

The company has also secured partnerships with tech giants like Foxconn, Apple, and Baidu.  

Prasad's story is a testament to the power of ambition, innovation, and the pursuit of one's passion.  His dedication to making communication more engaging has cemented his place as a leading figure in India's burgeoning tech landscape.

title: Samsung to Enter Tri-Fold Smartphone Market in 2025: Report
news:
Samsung is reportedly preparing to launch a tri-fold smartphone as early as next year, entering a market already occupied by competitor Huawei. This move comes as the South Korean tech giant seeks to stay ahead of the curve in the foldable phone market. 

Huawei's Mate XT Ultimate Edition, released in China, is a tri-fold device with a CNY 19,999 price tag (roughly Rs. 2,37,000). This device has reportedly prompted Samsung to accelerate their tri-fold development. 

Other smartphone brands like Xiaomi, Honor, and Oppo are also rumored to be working on tri-fold devices, but Samsung sees innovation as crucial to maintaining their dominant position in the foldable phone market. 

According to ZDNet Korea, Samsung is developing two foldable phones: an entry-level clamshell model and a more advanced tri-fold model. While the components for the tri-fold model are reportedly complete, the final launch decision rests with Samsung Electronics’ MX division.

However, the foldable phone market has not yet lived up to expectations, with sales falling short. Reports suggest that orders for foldable phone OLED displays dropped 10% compared to last year. This trend is attributed to lower-than-expected demand for Samsung's Galaxy Z Flip 6 and Galaxy Z Fold 6, prompting the company to reduce display production.

This isn’t the first time rumors of Samsung’s tri-fold ambitions surfaced. In March 2023, speculation emerged that Samsung might skip launching the Galaxy S23 FE in favor of a tri-fold device. While the S23 FE was later released, Samsung's continued experimentation with tri-fold designs is evident.

If Samsung launches a tri-fold phone, it could significantly impact consumer expectations for foldable devices, potentially appealing to users seeking a flexible and advanced mobile experience. However, with Huawei already in the market, Samsung will need to offer a truly innovative product to remain competitive.

title: Incomplete Ganga Lesson in UP Textbook: A Threat to Future Generations?
news:
A recent discovery in Uttar Pradesh's basic education board textbooks has sparked concern. The seventh-grade English textbook contains an inaccurate and incomplete account of the holy river Ganga, potentially misinforming young minds. The text claims that the Ganga originates from Gomukh, which is partially true. While the Bhagirathi river indeed flows from Gomukh, it is only after its confluence with the Alaknanda river at Devprayag that it officially becomes the Ganga. 

This error is a cause for alarm as it perpetuates misinformation about a culturally significant river among young students. This inaccurate information can have a detrimental impact on their understanding of the Ganga and its importance.

title: Seoul's Han River: A Lifeline Transformed
news:
The Future Hangang Project, set to be completed by 2030, is transforming Seoul's Han River from a simple waterway into a vibrant urban hub. Building on the 2007 Hangang Renaissance Project, which developed green spaces and a floating artificial island, the new project aims to integrate the river into the city's urban development. 

The 41.2-kilometer watercourse will see the construction of seven more floating islands, hosting hotels, restaurants, convention centers, and entertainment spaces.  This, coupled with the existing parks, promenades, and bike paths, will create a thriving recreational and cultural destination for Seoul residents and tourists alike. 

The project's director, Park Kinyong, highlights the importance of public-private partnerships to ensure the successful development of the river. The estimated $50 billion investment will create a new economic lifeline for Seoul, generating further economic activity and employment opportunities. 

The city's commitment to sustainable development is evident in the river's water quality management. The Han River receives treated water from four sewage and wastewater treatment plants, costing the city $730 million annually. Six drinking water purification systems upstream further ensure water quality. 

With a dedicated infrastructure network of express highways running along the 74 kilometers of the river within the Seoul Metropolitan City, the Han River is poised to become a pivotal element in the city's future growth and development.

title: Bangladesh in Turmoil as Protesters Demand President's Resignation
news:
Protests erupted in Bangladesh on Tuesday, October 22, demanding the resignation of President Mohammed Shahabuddin. The unrest stems from his comments on the resignation of former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. In an interview last week, the president stated he lacked documentary evidence of Hasina's resignation before she fled the country on August 5, 2024, amidst student-led protests.

Hundreds of protesters attempted to storm the presidential palace, leading to clashes with police who used sound grenades and even fired shots to contain the crowds. The military intervened and urged the protesters to leave.

The Anti-Discrimination Student Movement, a key player in Hasina's removal, is leading the charge for the president's resignation. They have issued a five-point demand, including the scrapping of the 1972 constitution.

The interim government, led by Nobel laureate Muhammad Yunus, has been criticized for failing to provide concrete evidence of Hasina's resignation. Law affairs adviser Asif Nazrul has accused the president of "falsehood" and suggested his position may be in jeopardy. 

Meanwhile, the president has urged the public not to reignite controversy over a "settled issue," maintaining that the interim government's legitimacy is supported by a Supreme Court ruling.

The situation in Bangladesh remains tense, with the protests raising significant questions about the future of the country's political landscape.

title: India's Green Hydrogen Ambitions Lag Behind
news:
India's ambitious goal of producing 1.1 metric tonnes of green hydrogen by 2030 may fall short, according to a new analysis by BloombergNEF. While the country has already tendered production capacity representing over 20% of this target, most investment proposals haven't reached the crucial stage of signing binding offtake contracts. This delay, coupled with the lack of green hydrogen consumption mandates in industries, forecasts a significantly lower production capacity of only 0.5 Mt/year by 2030, based on current project progress. 

The analysis further reveals that green hydrogen production costs in India currently range from $3-5 per kilogram, with potential federal subsidies reducing costs by 70 cents.  States like Uttar Pradesh offer generous incentives, potentially pushing costs down to $2/kg. This cost competitiveness makes green hydrogen a viable alternative to grey hydrogen, particularly for petroleum refineries. 

While most offtake agreements signed rely on exporting the clean fuel to advanced economies like Europe and Japan, the lack of strong local demand highlights the need for developing a mature domestic market.  The export route, however, offers an opportunity for green hydrogen producers to achieve economies of scale and lower production costs.

title: Final Report of Vadakkupattu Excavation Submitted to ASI
news:
The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has received the final report on the two-phase excavation conducted at Vadakkupattu village in Kancheepuram district, Tamil Nadu. The 700-page report, compiled by a team led by M. Kalimuthu, Superintending Archaeologist, ASI, Chennai Circle, was submitted to the ASI Director General, Yadubir Singh Rawat, in New Delhi on Tuesday.

The excavation, conducted over two years, aimed to uncover the history of the lower Palar River Valley palaeolithic site. The findings revealed a rich archaeological record spanning several periods, including the Middle Paleolithic Age, early historic, and the historic (Pallava) periods.

Significant artifacts unearthed during the excavation include:

* **Middle Paleolithic tools:** These indicate the presence of early human settlements in the area.
* **Early historic pottery:** This sheds light on the region's cultural development during the early historic period.
* **Bricks and several antiquities:** These provide insights into the building techniques and material culture of the time. 
* **Glass beads, carnelian beads, agate beads, glass bangles, terracotta figurines of humans and animals, wheels, spindle whorl, earrings, ornaments, seals, kaolin, gold and iron materials, and copper coins:** These artifacts reveal the diverse range of materials and craftsmanship prevalent during the various periods.

The report also highlights the discovery of potsherds with Tamil Brahmi script, known as 'Matti', and other potsherds with graffities. 

The ASI will now analyze the report and, upon approval, will publish its findings. This comprehensive report is expected to contribute significantly to our understanding of the history and culture of the lower Palar River Valley region.

title: Sonam Kapoor Acquires Mumbai's Famed Rhythm House for ₹47.8 Crore

Bhaane has confirmed the purchase and plans to expand its retail presence in Mumbai. The company already operates Nike and Converse stores in India. The sale is expected to breathe new life into the historic building, though details about the future of the space are yet to be disclosed.

title: Bengaluru's Flooded Underpasses: A Deadly Design Flaw
news:
Flooded underpasses in Bengaluru continue to pose a significant threat to commuters, with the latest incident highlighting the city’s ongoing struggle with monsoon preparedness. In May 2023, a 23-year-old tech professional tragically lost her life when her car was submerged at an underpass near K.R. Circle, sparking outrage and criticism of the Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP) for its lack of proactive measures.

Despite the tragedy, several underpasses across the city continue to flood during heavy rains, including those at Okalipuram, Panathur, and Madiwala Ayyappa Temple.  While the BBMP has implemented some temporary measures, like closing underpasses during heavy rainfall, these have been deemed insufficient. Experts point to the design flaws of these structures, particularly U-shaped underpasses, as the root cause of the problem. The lack of proper drainage systems and steep approach ramps contribute to the rapid accumulation of water, rendering these underpasses dangerous even during moderate rainfall.

The BBMP has proposed some remedial actions, including covering the roofs of U-shaped underpasses with galvanised sheets and desilting drains. While these steps are being implemented, experts argue that a more comprehensive approach is needed to address the underlying issues. This includes improving drainage infrastructure, redesigning underpasses with less steep ramps, and implementing a more robust maintenance schedule. 

The continued flooding of Bengaluru's underpasses poses a serious risk to public safety. The city authorities need to address this issue with a holistic approach, ensuring the safety and well-being of its citizens.

title: Kendriya Vihar Flooded Again, Residents Evacuated for Eight Days
news:
Heavy overnight rains in Bengaluru on Tuesday, October 22nd, caused flooding in North Bengaluru, specifically in Yelahanka and areas around Doddabommasandra Lake. Kendriya Vihar apartment complex, for the second time in two weeks, was inundated, forcing the BBMP (Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike) to evacuate residents for eight days.

BBMP Chief Commissioner, Tushar Giri Nath, inspected the affected areas, stating that the severe rains led to overflowing lakes and drains. A total of 4,000 houses across 10 layouts in the Yelahanka zone were affected, with water levels reaching up to six feet in Kendriya Vihar.

The BBMP arranged 16 boats for evacuating residents, with plans to add 10 more for faster evacuation. Residents have been advised to evacuate due to the forecast of rainfall for the next 3-4 days.

Amruth Kiran, a resident of Kendriya Vihar, reported a collapsed compound wall and higher water levels compared to the previous flooding. He stated that there would be no drinking water or power for the next 24-48 hours.

By evening, 80% of the residents had been evacuated with the help of the BBMP and NDRF personnel. The BBMP provided accommodation at a community hall, but most residents opted for friends', relatives' or hotel accommodations.

Kendriya Vihar, housing 604 apartments and 2,500 residents, has been temporarily protected with sandbags and a makeshift drain to facilitate water flow. 

Overflowing Doddabommasandra Lake also affected other North Bengaluru areas, including Tatanagar, Bhadrappa Layout, Balaji Layout, Kodigehalli, and Hebbal Sarovara. Water levels reached up to six feet in some areas, causing power outages.
