Shivakumar has vowed to take strict action against all responsible parties. The incident, which occurred on October 22nd, resulted in the death of a 26-year-old worker, with five others still trapped under the debris. 

Shivakumar, who visited the site, confirmed that the building was constructed without permission and illegal activities were taking place.  He declared that the owner, contractor, and all involved would be booked under the law. Rescue operations are currently underway, involving teams from the National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) and State Disaster Response Force (SDRF), as well as dog squads.

title: Paytm Gets Green Light to Onboard New UPI Users, But with Conditions
news:
Paytm, the Indian digital payments giant, has received approval from the National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI) to resume onboarding new users onto its Unified Payments Interface (UPI) platform. 

The approval comes after Paytm faced restrictions imposed by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) earlier this year. These restrictions prevented Paytm from adding new UPI users due to concerns about its compliance with regulations.

However, the NPCI's approval comes with a set of conditions. Paytm must adhere to all NPCI procedural guidelines and circulars, including those related to risk management, brand guidelines, multi-bank regulations, and customer data protection. The company must also comply with all applicable laws and regulations, including the Payments and Settlement Act, Information Technology Act, Digital Personal Data Protection Act, and regulations on data storage. 

This decision marks a significant step forward for Paytm, allowing it to expand its user base and potentially regain market share. However, the company must maintain strict adherence to the outlined conditions to ensure continued access to UPI services.

title: Modi and Xi to Meet for First Time in 5 Years Amidst Easing Border Tensions
news:
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Chinese President Xi Jinping are set to hold their first bilateral meeting in five years at the BRICS summit in Kazan, Russia on October 23rd, 2024. This meeting comes as India and China have worked to ease tensions along their disputed border, which saw a significant escalation in 2020. 

The meeting holds significance as it marks a potential step towards improving bilateral relations between the two Asian giants.  The summit in Kazan, Tatarstan, also provides a platform for discussions on various global issues including economics, security, and development.

title: Israel Confirms Killing of Hezbollah Leader in Airstrike
news:
The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) have confirmed the death of Hashem Safieddine, head of Hezbollah's executive council, in an airstrike on October 4th. Safieddine, considered a potential successor to Hassan Nasrallah, was killed alongside Hussein Ali Hazima, commander of Hezbollah's intelligence headquarters, in a strike targeting the organization's underground intelligence headquarters in Beirut.

The IDF claims the headquarters was located in a civilian area of the Lebanese capital. The airstrike was reported to have killed over 25 Hezbollah intelligence personnel, including several high-ranking commanders. 

Safieddine, a cousin of Nasrallah, played a key role in Hezbollah's decision-making processes and was responsible for directing attacks against Israel. He was designated a terrorist by the US State Department in 2017. 

Hezbollah has yet to issue a statement on Safieddine's death. The IDF previously confirmed the death of Hassan Nasrallah in a separate airstrike on September 28th.

title: Punjab Accuses Center of Deliberately Delaying Grain Procurement
news:
Punjab Finance Minister Harpal Singh Cheema has accused the central government of deliberately delaying the procurement of paddy from the state, calling it an unfair tactic against farmers. He claims the delay is a result of a "stepmotherly" attitude towards Punjab and its agricultural sector. 

Cheema highlighted Punjab's significant contribution to India's rice and wheat production, producing 12 tons of rice per hectare and contributing 22% of India's rice and 40% of its wheat despite having just 1.53% of the country's land.

The Aam Aadmi Party (AAP), the ruling party in Punjab, has alleged that the Food Corporation of India (FCI) is intentionally not clearing godowns, leading to the delay. 

Punjab Chief Minister Bhagwant Mann has urged Union Home Minister Amit Shah to intervene and ensure smooth procurement. Mann, during a phone call with Shah, highlighted issues like transportation costs, storage shortages, and the quality of hybrid varieties as factors impacting the procurement process.

The state government has made arrangements to ensure smooth procurement but has faced challenges like limited storage space and slow transportation leading to the delay. Mann also emphasized that 120 lakh metric tons of storage space remain occupied due to late milling from the previous season, urging the central government to address the issue and facilitate the release of this space.

title: Farmer Arrested for Electrocution Death of DMK Functionary’s Son in Vellore
news:
A 62-year-old farmer, K. Mohan, was arrested in Vellore on Tuesday for the death of a local DMK functionary’s son. Mohan had erected an illegal live power fence on his coconut grove, which led to the electrocution of 20-year-old S. Prasanth.

Prasanth went missing on October 12 while searching for his cows. His body was found on October 15, 500 meters from his house, bearing no signs of injury except for electrocution.

Police investigations revealed that Mohan had illegally connected a power line from an electric pole to the fence, intended to protect a well and motor pumpset on his land. Mohan has been produced before a local court and remanded to the Central Prison in Vellore.  Further investigations are ongoing.

title: Kasaragod Municipality Unveils Plans for Beach Park to Boost Tourism
news:
The Kasaragod municipality is set to transform the Nellikunnu beach into a major tourist attraction by constructing a beach park. The park, estimated to cost ₹1.75 crore, will be located opposite the Nellikunnu lighthouse and will feature amenities such as a café, play area, pathway, parking facilities, a toilet block, a selfie point, and solar lights. This initiative is part of the AMRUT 2.0 project, a collaborative effort between the Central and State governments and the municipality. 

The municipality is also planning a beach festival featuring beach games, a food festival, and art performances to further promote the area as a vibrant tourist destination. Officials believe that the beach park will be a turning point for Kasaragod's tourism sector, attracting visitors and boosting the local economy.

title: Kerala Holds First Transgender Aadhaar Enrolment Camp
news:
Kannur, Kerala hosted India's first dedicated Aadhaar enrolment camp for transgender individuals. This special event, held on October 23, 2024, aimed to simplify the process of updating Aadhaar details for transgender citizens. 

The camp, located at the Akshaya Kendra in Caltex Junction, allowed transgender individuals to update their names and correct their Aadhaar information using their transgender identity cards.  Biometric updates were also offered free of charge. 

The initiative was a collaborative effort between the District Transgender Justice Board, Social Justice department, Akshaya Project, and the Kerala State IT Mission, organized under instructions from the Central and State governments.  

The camp ensured transgender individuals could access these vital services without facing discrimination or bureaucratic hurdles.  It was coordinated by officials from various departments, including the Assistant Collector, District Social Justice Officer, and IT Mission District Project Manager.

While the camp focused on providing immediate assistance to transgender individuals, arrangements will be made to accommodate those unable to attend on the designated day.  This event marks a significant step towards inclusive access to essential services for the transgender community in Kerala.

title: Kerala Government to Crack Down on Unaided Schools Flouting Regulations
news:
The Kerala government is taking action against unaided educational institutions operating in violation of state and central regulations. This comes after reports of schools functioning without mandatory no-objection certificates (NOCs) and charging exorbitant fees. 

Minister for General Education, V. Sivankutty, has instructed the Director of General Education to submit a report within a month identifying these schools. The department has received complaints from parents who claim to have paid upwards of ₹5 lakh for admission to Class 2. 

Assistant Education Officers and District Education Officers will collect information regarding these violations. The government will then take necessary action, including cancellation of NOCs for non-compliant schools. 

The minister also announced that minimum marks will be required in each subject for students in Class 8 onwards, starting this academic year. Students who fail to achieve these minimum marks will be offered remedial classes and a re-test. 

In other news, the Kerala School Sports Meet, scheduled for November 4-11 in Kochi, will feature 41 sporting events and 24,000 athletes competing. The event will be modeled after the Olympics and will include a cultural performance by over 3,000 students. Students from eight schools in Gulf countries will also participate.  

Regarding the delayed renovations at Maharaja’s College stadium, the minister stated that the contractor has been instructed to increase manpower to expedite the process. However, the completion of the project remains contingent on weather conditions.

title: Student Groups Clash at Hospital, Damage Property
news:
A violent clash between activists from the Students' Federation of India (SFI) and the Kerala Students' Union (KSU) erupted at the Government Taluk Hospital in Karuvelipady, Kerala on Tuesday evening. The incident, which resulted in damage to hospital property including glass panes, stemmed from a dispute over flag hoisting at Cochin College.

The KSU accused SFI members of instigating violence at the hospital and attacking their members, while SFI blamed the KSU for the incident. The conflict escalated after SFI members allegedly refused to remove their flag from the college campus, where the KSU had recently won the college union election after six years. 

The KSU subsequently hoisted its flag, leading to clashes between the two groups. The violence spread from the college campus to the hospital, resulting in a tense situation.

title: Maradu Residents Protest Toll Fees Amid Bridge Closure
news:
Residents of Maradu, Kerala, staged a protest on Tuesday at the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) office, demanding a temporary exemption from toll fees at the Kumbalam plaza. The protest follows the NHAI’s refusal to grant the exemption requested by the Ernakulam District Collector. 

The residents are facing a significant inconvenience due to the closure of the Kundannoor and Alexander Parambithara bridges, which are undergoing resurfacing work. These bridges provide vital access to areas like Maradu and Kundannoor, connecting them to Willingdon Island and West Kochi. The closure forces commuters to take a detour through the toll plaza, adding an extra 10 kilometers to their journey.

The Maradu municipality, led by chairman Antony Ashanparambil, argues that the NHAI’s decision to deny the exemption is aimed at hindering the Collector’s request. They urged the NHAI to reconsider their stance and provide temporary relief for residents during the bridge closure period. 

The protest was temporarily suspended on the assurance that the issue would be escalated to higher authorities within the NHAI. Meanwhile, the Public Works Department (NH wing) is tasked with expediting the resurfacing work to minimize the inconvenience caused to the public.

title: Kochi School Embraces Innovation with New Tinkering Lab
news:
The Government Girls' Higher Secondary School in Thripunithura, Kochi, has opened a new "tinkering lab" aimed at fostering innovation and scientific temper among students. 

The lab, inaugurated by General Education Minister V. Sivankutty, is part of the World Bank-funded STARS (Strengthening Teaching-Learning and Results for States) initiative. This project, in collaboration with the Kerala Startup Mission, is establishing "Centres of Early Innovation" across the state.

Students from classes 6 to 11 will have access to laboratories focusing on electronics, artificial intelligence, and robotics. The key learning areas include STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) and arts. 

The Minister emphasized the initiative's role in equipping future generations with the digital skills necessary for future employment opportunities. The mini labs offer training in various fields like digital fabrication, 3D printing, and sensor technologies. 

This new facility is expected to transform learning into a more creative and engaging experience while nurturing young minds to become future innovators.

title: Shiv Sena Announces Candidates for Maharashtra Assembly Polls
news:
The Shiv Sena has released its first list of 45 candidates for the upcoming Maharashtra assembly elections in November. Chief Minister Eknath Shinde will contest from Kopri-Panchpakhadi in Thane city. 

The list includes several cabinet members, with Dada Bhuse contesting from Malegaon Outer, Uday Samant from Ratnagiri, and Tanaji Sawant from Paranda.  Sada Sarvankar will contest from Mahim in Mumbai. 

The party has also fielded family members of several MLAs, including Kiran Samant (brother of Uday Samant), Suhas Babar (son of the late Anil Babar), Manisha Waikar (wife of Ravindra Waikar), and Abhijit Adsul (son of Anand Adsul).

The Shiv Sena's move makes them the second major political party to release their candidate list, following the BJP's announcement of 99 candidates last Sunday. The ruling Mahayuti coalition, comprising the BJP, Shiv Sena, and NCP, has yet to finalize their seat-sharing agreement for the upcoming polls.

title: Modi and Xi to Meet on the Sidelines of BRICS Summit
news:
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Chinese President Xi Jinping will hold a bilateral meeting on October 23, 2024, in Kazan, Russia, on the sidelines of the BRICS summit. This will be their first structured meeting since the border standoff in eastern Ladakh began in May 2020. 

The meeting comes a day after India and China reached an agreement on patrolling by their militaries along the Line of Actual Control (LAC) in eastern Ladakh, marking a significant step towards ending the four-year standoff. The agreement focuses on reverting patrolling and grazing activities to the situation that existed in 2020.

This meeting is expected to focus on discussing the implementation of the newly signed agreement and potentially exploring further steps towards de-escalation and troop disengagement. While the details of the meeting remain undisclosed, it is a crucial step in re-establishing dialogue and potentially improving the strained relations between the two Asian giants.

title: BSNL Launches 7 New Services Ahead of Diwali, Challenging Reliance Jio
news:
In a bid to gain market share amidst rising mobile tariffs from competitors like Reliance Jio, Airtel and Vodafone Idea, state-owned telecom provider BSNL has launched 7 new services. These include:

* **Spam Blockers:**  BSNL has implemented anti-spam solutions to protect users from phishing and malicious messages.
* **Automated SIM Kiosks:** These 24/7 kiosks offer  SIM card purchase, transfer, upgrades, and payment options via UPI or QR codes. They also streamline KYC processes for a more convenient experience.
* **Direct-to-Device Connectivity:**  This service combines satellite and mobile networks, ensuring continued connectivity even in emergency situations or remote areas. 
* **Low Latency 5G Connectivity:**  BSNL, in collaboration with CDAC, has launched high-speed 5G connectivity for mining operations, utilizing homegrown equipment.

These initiatives highlight BSNL's commitment to innovation and customer satisfaction, aiming to compete directly with Reliance Jio and other major players in the Indian telecommunications market.

title: Mumbai Bans Sky Lanterns and Fireworks in Certain Areas Ahead of Diwali
news:
The Mumbai Police has banned the sale and flying of sky lanterns throughout the city from October 23rd to November 21st. This measure, implemented under Section 163 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, aims to prevent potential safety hazards and anti-social activity. 

The ban extends to the storage and use of sky lanterns, citing concerns about public safety and potential damage to property. This follows a separate order issued on October 19th prohibiting fireworks within 500 meters of oil and fuel companies, including Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd. and Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Ltd. 

Specific areas affected by the firework ban include:

* Outside perimeter area of Bharat Petroleum Corporation Lid., and Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Ltd., Refinery
* Mahul Terminal Area
* Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd. Plant Area
* Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Ltd., Plant Area.
* Behind 15 and 50 acres area up to Special Oil Refinery

The Mumbai Police has stated that these orders are routine preventive measures reviewed and updated every 30 days.

title: Hezbollah Drone Attack Targets Netanyahu's Home in Caesarea
news:
Hezbollah has claimed responsibility for a drone attack that targeted Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's home in Caesarea. Images of damage to the residence have emerged. While Netanyahu was not present at the time of the attack, he has condemned it as a "grave mistake."  

The attack, which has been described as an "assassination attempt" by some sources, has raised tensions in the region. Iran, a key backer of Hezbollah, has also alleged that the group was behind the drone attack.

title: NGT Criticizes Water Resources Department for Slow Removal of Invasive Mussels
news:
The National Green Tribunal (NGT) has expressed dissatisfaction with the Water Resources Department (WRD) for its slow progress in removing invasive charru mussels from the Ennore wetlands. Despite repeated orders, the WRD has only shown minimal progress, prompting the NGT to demand an explanation. 

The NGT observed that the only evidence presented by the WRD were photographs of mechanical removal efforts at three locations: Kattupalli, Puzhuthivakkam, and Athipattu.  However, the photographs indicated that action was taken only on October 20th, despite the order being issued on October 3rd. Furthermore, the images showed only one person and one machine being used for the removal process.

The NGT highlighted the detrimental impact of charru mussels, known locally as "kaaka aazhi," on water bodies, biodiversity, and boat movement. The Bench expressed concern over the delay in removal and the lack of a comprehensive plan and schedule for the operation. 

The NGT has given the WRD a final chance to explain their hesitancy in promptly addressing the issue and has requested a report by October 24th.

title: Bengaluru Braces for More Rain: IMD Forecast
news:
Bengaluru is expected to experience more rainfall over the next 24 hours, according to the India Meteorological Department (IMD). Moderate rain and thundershowers, potentially heavy at times, are anticipated. The city already received 23.3 mm of rainfall in the nine hours ending at 5.30 p.m. on Tuesday. 

The IMD forecasts a continuation of widespread rainfall in southern interior Karnataka until Thursday, with coastal Karnataka experiencing fairly widespread rainfall and northern interior Karnataka experiencing scattered rainfall during the same period.

A yellow alert has been issued for Wednesday for Belagavi, Dharwad, Haveri, Gadag, Shivamogga, Chikkamagaluru, Chitradurga, Davangere, Tumakuru, Chickballapur, Kolar, Bengaluru, Ramanagara, and Mandya districts, anticipating moderate to very heavy rainfall in isolated areas.

title: Haryana Cracks Down on Stubble Burning: 16 Farmers Arrested, 22 FIRs Filed
news:
Haryana authorities have taken a hard line against stubble burning, arresting 16 farmers and filing 22 FIRs in the district of Kaithal over the past week. The action comes as part of the state's ongoing effort to combat air pollution caused by crop residue burning.

The FIRs were registered under sections related to disobedience of orders by public servants and violation of the Air Pollution Act. While the accused farmers were released on bail, the Haryana agriculture department has also implemented a stricter policy: farmers caught burning stubble will have a red entry marked in their e-portal, preventing them from selling their crops at mandis for the next two years.

The government is also actively promoting alternative methods of crop residue management, such as baling, and providing financial incentives to farmers who adopt these practices.

The move has drawn criticism from opposition politician Abhay Chautala, who called the government's actions "anti-farmer" and "dictatorial." He argued that mixing crop residue into the field is a more effective solution, and advocated for government compensation of ₹3,000 per acre for farmers who choose this method. 

Despite the controversy, the Haryana government remains committed to curbing stubble burning and has reported a significant decrease in cases compared to the previous year.

title: Building Collapse in Bengaluru: One Dead, Several Trapped
news:
A multi-storey building under construction collapsed in Bengaluru, Karnataka on Tuesday evening, October 22nd. The incident resulted in one fatality and left several others trapped within the rubble. 

Rescue efforts are ongoing, with 14 people already rescued and 5 still missing. Authorities are working to safely extract those trapped and determine the cause of the collapse.

title: Supreme Court to Rule on Centre-State Power Struggle Over Industrial Alcohol
news:
The Supreme Court of India will issue its verdict on October 23rd regarding a dispute between the central government and several states over the control of industrial alcohol. The case revolves around the respective authorities' power to tax, manufacture, and produce alcohol.

The central government argues that it has exclusive control over industrial alcohol as it is an "industry" overseen by the Union government under a parliamentary law. This argument is based on Entry 52 of the Union List in the Seventh Schedule of the Constitution, which grants the central government control over "industries" including the trade and commerce of their products.

States, however, argue that they have the power to regulate the flow of industrial alcohol within their jurisdictions to prevent its misuse for human consumption. They emphasize the potential for denatured spirit (industrial alcohol) to be illegally converted into potable liquor, posing a serious threat to public health. 

This case is critical as it has the potential to redefine the balance of power between the central government and states in areas of taxation and alcohol regulation. The Supreme Court's decision will have significant implications for both public health and economic policy in India.

title: Bihar's Ambitious Sports Plan: From University to Olympics
news:
Bihar is making a bold push towards becoming a sporting powerhouse, with its focus on talent development and infrastructure. The state government has established a new sports university and a state-of-the-art sports complex in Rajgir, aiming to train athletes in 23 disciplines. This initiative is spearheaded by Raveendran Sankaran, BSSA Director General, who outlines a comprehensive strategy to propel Bihar onto the international sports stage.

The university, costing ₹740 crore, aims to integrate academic learning with practical training. It will offer short courses in sports science, nutrition, and physiotherapy, with the long-term goal of becoming a regional hub for sports excellence. 

Sankaran outlines a strategic approach to talent identification, focusing on disciplines like rugby sevens, fencing, and sepak takraw, which are well-suited for Bihar's unique strengths. He emphasizes a "Medal lao, naukri pao" (Win a medal, get a job) policy, offering employment to national-level medalists to encourage participation. 

The state is also investing in infrastructure development, including a new indoor sports complex and a multi-purpose complex in Patna. The government's commitment to sports is evident in the significant budget increase from ₹30 crore to ₹680 crore.

By 2028, Bihar aims to see its athletes compete at the Los Angeles Olympics, with medal ambitions for 2032 and 2036. This ambitious plan hinges on a comprehensive approach that combines infrastructure, training, and a strong focus on talent development, making Bihar a state to watch in the world of sports.

title: Congress and SP to Contest UP Bypolls Together
news:
The Congress and Samajwadi Party (SP) have announced they will contest the upcoming Uttar Pradesh Assembly bypolls together, aiming to defeat the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP). The bypolls are scheduled for nine Assembly seats: Katehari, Karhal, Meerapur, Ghaziabad, Majhawan, Sisamau, Khair, Phulpur, and Kundarki. 

The bypoll for the vacant Milkipur seat is not being held due to a pending election petition in the Allahabad High Court. 

Congress President Ajay Rai stated that the INDIA bloc, a coalition of opposition parties, will fight together, regardless of the outcome of seat-sharing talks with the SP. He criticized the BJP, accusing them of instigating riots, carrying out fake encounters, and implementing policies harmful to farmers, women, the poor, Scheduled Castes, and minorities.

While the two parties have not finalized seat sharing, the SP has reportedly offered Ghaziabad and Khair to the Congress.

title: Ancient Jain Beds Discovered in Madurai: A Hidden Heritage Threatened by Quarrying
news:
Archaeologists have uncovered 12 Jain beds, dating back almost 2,000 years, nestled within a rocky hillock called Aruvimalai near Madurai, Tamil Nadu.  These beds, carved into the cliff face, are a testament to the region's rich religious history and coexistence between Jainism and Hinduism.  However, the site faces a looming threat from nearby quarrying operations, raising concerns about the preservation of this valuable historical landmark.

The discovery was made by researchers from the Madurai Nature Cultural Foundation (MNCF) who documented the beds, which, unlike other Jain sites in the area, lack traditional inscriptions and sculptures.  Though the beds have been noted by locals, their significance was previously overlooked. 

The MNCF is now advocating for the Tamil Nadu State Department of Archaeology to declare the site a protected area, arguing that the site is not only historically important but also holds potential for boosting tourism in the region. Currently, many other Jain sites in the district, such as those in Keelavalavu, Thiruvathavur, Varichiyur, and Karungalakkudi, remain largely unknown to tourists.

The presence of quarrying operations poses a significant threat to the preservation of these beds. The MNCF believes that declaring the site protected would not only safeguard the beds, but also attract tourists, contributing to the local economy.

title: Karnataka Congress Calls for Second Bengaluru Airport to Boost South Region's Growth
news:
A group of Karnataka Congress legislators has submitted a memorandum to the state government urging the construction of a second international airport in Bengaluru's southern region. This move, they argue, will fuel economic growth in the region, improve connectivity, and alleviate congestion at the existing Kempegowda International Airport (KIA) in the north.

The legislators, citing the numerous passengers traveling from the south to KIA, point to the existing infrastructure like the Namma Metro, NICE Road, and the newly-developed Bengaluru-Mysuru expressway as facilitating easy access to a potential southern airport. They believe this new airport would benefit residents of Electronics City, Bommanahalli, Bannerghatta, and other southern localities. 

Additionally, the proposed airport's location in the south would offer easy connectivity to the industrial hub of Bidadi and stimulate tourism in Ramanagara, Mandya, Maddur, Srirangapatna, and Mysuru. The legislators call on the state cabinet to take a decision on the location and initiate land acquisition for the project.

The Karnataka government, represented by Industries and Infrastructure Minister M.B. Patil, is considering several potential sites and will factor in passenger density, connectivity, industrial growth, cargo potential, and environmental considerations in making a final decision. 

The government aims to complete the second airport by 2033.

title: Accusing Gauri Lankesh Murder Accused Felicitators of Abetting Murder, Activists Demand Action
news:
Activists in Dharwad, Karnataka, have condemned the recent felicitation of individuals accused in the murder of journalist Gauri Lankesh. Members of the Gauri Smaraka Trust and Gauri Balaga staged a protest on Tuesday, calling the act a disgrace to humanity and the Constitution. 

They argue that felicitating the accused, who are currently out on bail, amounts to instigating and encouraging violence.  The protesters demanded legal action, including charges of abetment to murder, against those involved in the felicitation. 

Further, they urged the state government to take action against the communal organization they allege is inciting violence and vengeance.  The group also called for expedited proceedings in the Gauri Lankesh murder case and swift punishment for the guilty. 

The activists submitted a memorandum to the Home Minister through the district administration, demanding swift action on their demands.

title: A DMK Nominee's Age Scandal:  Rajya Sabha Disqualification 50 Years Ago
news:
In 1974, the DMK, holding a commanding majority in the Tamil Nadu Assembly, faced an embarrassing setback when one of their Rajya Sabha candidates, Valampuri John, was disqualified for being underaged. John, a prominent advocate and writer, had declared his age as 31, but opponents questioned this, citing his school records and Bar Council registration.

The Madras High Court ultimately ruled in favor of the challengers, deeming John ineligible. Despite appealing to the Supreme Court, John's election was overturned. This incident highlights the importance of age verification in political elections, especially for positions with age requirements. It also serves as a reminder that even the most powerful parties are not immune to scrutiny and legal challenges.

title: India and Pakistan Renew Kartarpur Corridor Agreement for Five Years
news:
India and Pakistan have agreed to extend their agreement on the Kartarpur Corridor for another five years, until 2029. The corridor, opened in 2019, allows Sikh pilgrims from India to visit the sacred Gurdwara Darbar Sahib in Kartarpur, Pakistan, where Guru Nanak, the founder of Sikhism, spent his final days.

The renewal comes despite strained relations between the two countries. India has, however, expressed its disappointment that Pakistan continues to levy a $20 service charge per pilgrim, a fee India has urged be waived.

While the agreement signifies a continued channel of communication, India's efforts to convince Pakistan to remove the service charge have been unsuccessful. Pakistan maintains that the charge is necessary to cover the cost of refurbishing the Gurdwara and the construction of infrastructure for pilgrims.

The corridor has seen a decline in the number of pilgrims since its opening, despite the daily quota of 5,000 pilgrims set by Pakistan.

title: Balancing Innovation and Ethics Globally: Rishabh Shanbhag's AI Leadership
news:
Rishabh Shanbhag, an innovative AI architect, is leading the charge in ethical and cross-industry AI implementation. His work spans diverse sectors, demonstrating the transformative potential of responsible AI in enterprise solutions.

**AI Across Industries:** Shanbhag emphasizes the unique challenges and opportunities each sector presents. His experience includes developing predictive models for engineering, student intervention systems for education, multi-threat detection systems for defense, and optimized data engineering for pharmaceuticals. 

**Ethical Considerations:** Shanbhag prioritizes ethical AI implementation and robust privacy protection. He advocates for integrating ethical considerations into system design, emphasizing the importance of balancing innovation with individual privacy and societal values. 

**Key Ethical Practices:** Shanbhag implements stringent data handling protocols, privacy-preserving features like real-time image blurring, and transparent, interpretable AI insights. He also prioritizes secure handling of sensitive information and multi-level encryption for AI-powered chatbots.

**Future of AI in Business:** Shanbhag envisions AI as an indispensable partner in decision-making across all levels, from strategy formulation to addressing global challenges. He predicts AI-driven sustainable decisions, workforce augmentation through new roles, hyper-personalized experiences, global collaboration, and robust ethical AI governance frameworks.

**Shanbhag's Contributions:**  He has demonstrated the transformative power of AI through tangible results like reduced energy costs, improved accuracy in defense systems, accelerated drug discovery, and enhanced customer engagement. His work at industry giants like AWS and Walmart highlights the potential of AI to revolutionize enterprise solutions while upholding ethical standards.

**Empowering Ethical AI Innovation:**  Shanbhag's approach inspires action. Key takeaways for ethical AI implementation include:

* Conducting ethical AI audits.
* Drawing inspiration from cross-industry AI solutions.
* Committing to continuous learning in the rapidly evolving AI landscape.
* Collaborating for impact.
* Starting small and thinking big.
* Sharing experiences and insights.

Shanbhag's commitment to ethical AI underscores its potential to drive progress across industries while upholding the highest standards of innovation.

title: Old Mahabalipuram Road: A Late-Night Food Paradise
news:
Old Mahabalipuram Road (OMR), a bustling hub for IT companies and startups, has also become a haven for late-night food lovers.  Known as V.M. Food Street, this stretch boasts a diverse range of eateries catering to every taste bud and budget.

The street comes alive after noon, offering everything from crispy fried chicken and burgers to ice cream and waffles, with many shops staying open until late at night. This has become a popular destination for college students, IT professionals, and anyone seeking a delicious late-night bite. 

The high demand for food is fueled by the numerous hostels, paying guest accommodations, and mansions housing individuals who work late. The area's large IT presence also contributes to the late-night food scene, as many employees seek snacks after their workday ends.

Despite current traffic congestion due to Metro Rail construction, residents are optimistic that footfall will increase once the project is complete. The convenient location and affordable prices make V.M. Food Street a popular choice for locals and visitors alike.

title: Elon Musk's Starlink Takes a Giant Leap: Satellite-Based Calling Without SIMs
news:
Elon Musk's satellite internet network, Starlink, has taken a major step forward in its mission to revolutionize communication. A successful test in New Zealand demonstrated the ability to send and receive SMS messages via satellite, eliminating the need for traditional SIM cards. 

The test, conducted by ONE NZ NETWORK, involved sending an SMS from a satellite to a mobile phone in Christchurch. This achievement supports Musk's ongoing requests for spectrum allocation from governments,  aimed at enabling broader satellite-based communication. 

While the test focused on SMS, Musk has indicated that broader testing, including phone calls, will begin during the Christmas holidays. 

This development signifies a significant shift in the telecommunications landscape, potentially offering a new level of connectivity and accessibility, particularly in remote areas. It remains to be seen how this technology will be integrated into existing networks and how it will affect the global telecommunications market.

title: Coral's Curious Influence on Madras' Business
news:
Coral, a seemingly simple marine invertebrate, played a surprisingly significant role in the economic history of Madras (now Chennai) during the 17th and 18th centuries. While the city's Sephardic Jewish merchants were known for trading in various precious stones, coral stands out as a key commodity that shaped their business interests and left its mark on the city's geography.

The red coral, sourced from the Mediterranean, was highly prized in India since Roman times. This demand intensified under colonial rule, with European traders recognizing a lucrative opportunity. Portuguese Jewish dealers in London established a network to supply vast quantities of coral to Madras, where it was traded for diamonds destined for Europe. 

Coral's influence went beyond mere trade. Historical records indicate that it played a critical role in the wealth and power struggles of prominent figures. Samudra Mudali, a prominent official, amassed his fortune through a clandestine coral sale, while Governor Dupleix sought information on coral stock and prices. George, Lord Pigot, a notoriously corrupt governor, even secured a commission on coral sales, which became a source of conflict and ultimately contributed to his downfall.

While the exact reasons for the immense demand for coral are not entirely clear, its use in jewelry and as an ingredient in aphrodisiacs is widely documented. By the 19th century, coral's prominence began to wane, eventually becoming just another component in ornaments. 

Despite its eventual decline, coral’s influence on Madras’s economy, its role in shaping the lives of key historical figures, and its lasting impact on the city’s geography remain intriguing testaments to its unique place in the city's history.

title: Heavy Rains Disrupt Life in Coimbatore, Schools Closed
news:
Coimbatore and Tiruppur districts in Tamil Nadu were hit by heavy rainfall on Tuesday, causing widespread disruption. The downpour, which lasted for over two hours, was accompanied by thunder and lightning, catching many motorists off guard.

Schools and colleges in both districts were closed on Wednesday, October 23, due to the heavy rains.  Coimbatore District Collector Kranthi Kumar Pati announced the holiday for schools in his district, citing the disruptive weather conditions.

Bus services were severely affected by the rain, leaving many stranded passengers seeking shelter under overpasses.  Pedestrians in low-lying areas of Coimbatore faced challenges navigating knee-deep water, with reports of two vehicles becoming stuck in rising waters.

The Tiruppur district administration issued a flood alert for areas surrounding the Amaravathy Dam in Udumalpet, as the dam's water level reached 85.24 feet on Tuesday evening. The continuous rainfall in the catchment area led to the alert, with the district collector T. Christuraj warning of potential water releases should the dam reach capacity.

Despite the challenging conditions, there were no reported casualties, according to local sources.

title: Karnataka HC Halts Final BBMP Advertisement Bylaws
news:
The Karnataka High Court has ordered the State government to refrain from notifying the final Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike (BBMP) Advertisement Bylaws, 2024, without prior court approval. This directive comes in response to a series of Public Interest Litigation (PIL) petitions filed since 2017, highlighting the BBMP and State government’s failure to address illegal hoardings. 

The court initiated a suo motu PIL in July this year,  specifically addressing the lack of implementation of previous court directives aimed at tackling the issue.  While the government advocate stated that the BBMP had sent communications to the government regarding the draft bylaws, the court has mandated that the final bylaws be submitted to the court for review before official notification. 

Previous court hearings have emphasized the need for stringent penal provisions within the bylaws to deter violations and ensure continuous monitoring of unauthorized advertisements. The court has also suggested that the bylaws should restrict the placement of flexes and hoardings near pedestrian pathways.

title: CPI(ML) Announces Candidates for Jharkhand Polls,  Seat-Sharing Talks With INDIA Bloc Stalled
news:
The Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist) Liberation (CPI(ML)) has announced its first list of candidates for the upcoming Jharkhand assembly elections. The party has fielded Rajkumar Yadav from Dhanwar, Bablu Mahto from Sindri, and Arup Chatterjee from Nirsa. These seats are scheduled for polls in the second phase, which will take place on November 20.

The announcement comes as the CPI(ML)'s negotiations with the JMM and Congress,  part of the INDIA alliance, for seat-sharing have hit a standstill. The CPI(ML) had initially expressed interest in contesting 12 seats but are now willing to settle for five. However, the JMM has been reluctant to concede Dhanwar, a seat the CPI(ML) has held since 1995.

The CPI(ML) is confident in its chances in these three seats, claiming to have outperformed the JMM-Congress alliance in the 2019 elections. The party is particularly strong in Nirsa and Sindri, where the Marxist Coordination Committee (MCC), which has now merged with the CPI(ML), has a substantial presence.

The CPI(ML) is yet to finalize its candidate for the Bagodar constituency, where their sitting MLA, Vinod Singh, is seeking re-election. Mr. Singh has indicated that the party will release a second list of candidates if no breakthrough is achieved in the talks with the JMM and Congress.

title: Karnataka High Court Seeks Report on Darshan's Medical Condition
news:
The Karnataka High Court has requested a report on the medical condition of actor Darshan, who is currently facing charges in the Renukaswamy murder case. The request follows Darshan's lawyer's claim that doctors have recommended surgery for the actor's back pain.

Darshan's legal team is seeking bail for the actor on medical grounds, arguing that he needs surgery as per medical advice. The court, led by Justice S. Vishwajith Shetty, has directed the prosecution to submit Darshan's medical report by October 28th.

The actor's bail plea was previously rejected by the trial court on October 14th. The court cited strong evidence suggesting Darshan's involvement in the alleged crime and expressed concerns about potential witness intimidation if he were released on bail.

The court also rejected the argument that Darshan's release was necessary for the livelihood of numerous individuals dependent on his film projects. The court maintained that granting special treatment based on status would violate the principle of equality before the law.

title: Congress to Field Tukaram's Wife for Sandur Bypoll
news:
The ruling Congress party in Karnataka has confirmed that Annapurna, wife of Ballari MP E. Tukaram, will be the party's candidate for the upcoming Sandur (ST) byelection. This decision was announced by Karnataka Chief Minister Siddaramaiah, who revealed that the party is expected to make an official announcement on candidates for all three byelection constituencies within the next few days. 

The bypolls are scheduled for November 13th and will be held in the Sandur, Shiggaon, and Channapatna assembly constituencies. The decision to field Annapurna in Sandur comes after Tukaram met with Siddaramaiah and Deputy Chief Minister D.K. Shivakumar to discuss her candidacy. 

While the candidate for Sandur is now confirmed, the party is still considering candidates for the remaining two constituencies.  The Chief Minister hinted that D.K. Suresh, brother of D.K. Shivakumar, is a strong contender for the Channapatna seat.

title: India Launches Fourth Nuclear Submarine, Bolstering Deterrence
news:
India has successfully launched its fourth nuclear-powered ballistic missile submarine (SSBN), designated S4*, into the water at the Ship Building Centre in Visakhapatnam. This new submarine surpasses its predecessors in size and capability, boasting a larger payload and the ability to deploy the advanced K-4 submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM).

The K-4, which was first tested in 2020, has a range of 3,500 km and will be the primary weapon in India's underwater nuclear deterrent. It provides India with a significant standoff capability, enabling the launch of nuclear weapons from within its territorial waters. This strengthens India's "Credible Minimum Deterrence" (CMD) strategy, a policy emphasizing a robust and survivable retaliatory capacity while maintaining a "No First Use" commitment to nuclear weapons.

The S4* is the latest addition to India's growing nuclear submarine fleet. The first SSBN, INS Arihant, was commissioned in 2016. It is equipped with the K-15 SLBM with a range of 750km. The second SSBN, INS Arighaat, was commissioned in August of this year, while the third, Aridhman, is undergoing sea trials.

The launch of the S4* marks a significant step forward in India's nuclear capabilities and signals the nation's commitment to a robust deterrence strategy. It is expected to play a vital role in maintaining regional stability and projecting India's growing power in the Indo-Pacific region.

title: AIDWA Protests Wine Shop Opening in Visakhapatnam
news:
The All India Democratic Women’s Association (AIDWA) is protesting the opening of a wine shop in the Bhupesh Nagar area of Visakhapatnam. They argue that the presence of nearly five wine shops in the locality will increase vulnerability for women, who already feel insecure. 

AIDWA leader Satyavathi stated that the government's focus on liquor revenue is ignoring the concerns of local residents. She cited an incident where an elderly man was attacked and robbed by intoxicated individuals, highlighting the potential for increased crime. The group also criticized politicians who justify liquor sales by claiming they are necessary for funding welfare schemes. 

The AIDWA has staged a protest for four consecutive days at Bhupesh Nagar, demanding action against the opening of the new wine shop.

title: Trump and Harris Court Latino Voters with Economic Promises
news:
With the U.S. Presidential election just two weeks away, both Kamala Harris and Donald Trump are focusing on economic policies to attract Latino voters. 

Harris, the Democratic nominee, emphasizes her plan to create more opportunities for Latino men through initiatives like doubling registered apprenticeships, removing college degree requirements for federal jobs, and providing forgivable loans to small businesses. 

Trump, the Republican nominee, is highlighting his economic record during his presidency, claiming increased employment, wages, and home ownership for Latinos. He criticizes the current administration's policies, blaming them for high inflation and vowing to bring "prosperity back to America." 

Both campaigns recognize the potential influence of Latino men, who could swing the outcome in key states like Pennsylvania, Arizona, and Nevada. 

The election will likely hinge on whether voters are persuaded by Trump's claim of past economic success or Harris' promise of new policies aimed at creating more opportunities.

title: Kochi Metro Extension Faces Delays, Frustrating Residents
news:
The much-anticipated Kakkanad extension of the Kochi Metro is facing delays, with residents and local authorities expressing frustration over the slow pace of construction. 

While the Kochi Metro Rail Limited (KMRL) has promised an 18-month completion timeline for the 11.20-km viaduct, concerns linger regarding the lack of progress at many of the construction sites along Civil Line Road. This key road, leading from the city to the IT hub and other important areas in Kakkanad, has been partially barricaded for the project. 

The delay in widening the road and the absence of construction activity at several barricaded sites have resulted in severe traffic congestion and inconvenience for residents, especially children and elderly individuals. The Thrikkakara Development Forum (TDF) and local MLA Uma Thomas have repeatedly urged the KMRL to expedite the process and develop alternative routes to alleviate traffic woes. 

The KMRL has attributed the delays to various factors, including the relocation of electric and telecom posts, geotechnical studies, and court cases hindering work at certain locations. They assure that off-site and pre-casting works are in full swing, with approximately 60% of the construction taking place at the Kalamassery casting yard. 

However, with the deadline for road widening already passed and ongoing traffic headaches, the KMRL faces pressure to accelerate the project and provide a solution to the mounting frustration of residents.

title: Doctors Weigh in on Controversial YouTuber's Hospital Video
news:
The recent video posted by YouTuber Irfan, showcasing his newborn in an operating room, has sparked a debate on social media regarding hospital practices, patient privacy, and ethical concerns.  Doctors in Chennai have shared their perspectives on the complexities involved, with particular focus on the presence of partners in labor and delivery rooms.

Dr. Kanimozhi N.V.N. Somu, a physician and Rajya Sabha Member, emphasizes that there's no set rule regarding a husband's presence in the delivery room. The decision rests primarily with the doctor and hospital management, with increasing acceptance of husbands being present for vaginal deliveries.  However, for cesarean sections, the decision remains at the discretion of the medical team due to the sterile environment and potential for distraction.

Dr. Jaishree Gajaraj, a senior consultant obstetrician and gynecologist, shares a similar viewpoint, stating that while many doctors allow husbands in the labor room, she personally prefers to limit their presence in the operating room due to potential distraction.  She suggests that allowing partners during Cesareans under spinal anesthesia is acceptable, as the mother is awake and can maintain privacy. However, if a woman is under general anesthesia, only medical personnel should be present. 

Other doctors have noted that while some hospitals permit husbands to cut the umbilical cord during vaginal deliveries, this should always be at the request of the mother.

The controversy surrounding Irfan's video also highlights the need for clear protocols regarding video recording and posting on social media. Dr. Kanimozhi underscores that while husbands are present to provide support, they should not be recording and sharing sensitive medical procedures without proper consent.  Dr. Jaishree emphasizes the need for consent from both hospital management and the surgeon involved.

All doctors stress the importance of maintaining a sterile environment in the operating room, and highlight the potential risks of infection if proper hygiene protocols are not followed.  Dr. Vijaya, president of the Obstetric and Gynaecological Society of Southern India, reiterates that non-medical personnel should never be allowed in the operating room, particularly during Cesarean sections, where the uterus is open. 

The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of maintaining patient privacy, respecting the sterile environment of operating rooms, and adhering to clear protocols for video recording in medical settings.

title: Coimbatore Flyover Safety Concerns Amidst UGD Works
news:
Ongoing underground drainage (UGD) works near the Trichy Road flyover at Ramanathapuram junction in Coimbatore have raised concerns about the safety of the structure.  

Recent reports indicate that soil near the flyover pillar collapsed during UGD excavation, prompting worries about the adequacy of safety measures. While officials from the Highways Department claim ignorance of the incident, K. Kathirmathiyon, secretary of Coimbatore Consumer Cause, emphasizes the importance of proper inspection and monitoring of the site. 

He stresses that the UGD agency should have consulted with the Highways Department to ensure safe excavation distances from the flyover pillars. He also underscores the need for regular inspections by the Highways Department to guarantee the pillar's structural integrity. 

This incident highlights a broader concern regarding accountability and safety protocols in infrastructure projects within the city.

title: Tungabhadra Dam Water Release Increased Due to Heavy Rainfall
news:
The Tungabhadra Dam authorities have increased water release to 1,12,136 cusecs following heavy rainfall in the dam's catchment area.  This increase is attributed to the high inflow from the Tunga and Bhadra dams, as well as heavy rainfall in the Sahyadri Range and Malnad region.

As of Tuesday evening, the reservoir held 101.461 tmcft of water, close to its full capacity of 105.788 tmcft. The average inflow over the past 24 hours was 1,04,663 cusecs, with the hourly inflow reaching 1,12,136 cusecs by 5 p.m. 

The dam authorities, while maintaining water release into canals, increased the release into the river course to 1,01,628 cusecs to match the inflow. An alert was issued earlier in the day, warning of a potential increase in water release to 1,20,000 cusecs depending on the inflow. People downstream were advised to take necessary precautions.

title: Kerala Launches "Ente Bhoomi" – India's First Comprehensive Digital Land Management System
news:
Kerala has taken a significant leap forward in land management with the launch of "Ente Bhoomi" (My Land) – India's first integrated digital land information management system (ILIMS). This comprehensive platform, launched by Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan, brings together services from Survey, Revenue, and Registration departments, offering a simplified experience for citizens. 

Ente Bhoomi allows users to access a wide range of services online, including:

* **Land Transfer:** Streamlined procedures for transferring land ownership.
* **Land Registration:** A template system for quick and efficient land registration.
* **Pre-Mutation Sketch:** Obtaining a sketch of land before official mutation.
* **Liability Certificate:** Verifying potential liabilities associated with a property.
* **Land Tax Payment:** Convenient online payment of land taxes.
* **Fair Value Determination:** Automated valuation of properties.
* **Auto Mutation:** Automatic updating of land records.
* **Location Sketch:** Obtaining a digital sketch of land location.

The system is currently operational in 212 villages, covering 4.8 lakh hectares of land. The goal is to expand the service to all digitally surveyed villages within three months. 

"Ente Bhoomi" aims to improve transparency and efficiency in land services, offering benefits not just to residents but also to the Kerala diaspora. The portal is already accessible in 10 countries, with plans to expand to other nations. This digital initiative signifies a significant step towards modernizing land management practices in India.

title: Four Peafowls Found Dead in Thoothukudi Village
news: On Tuesday, four peafowls were found dead in a farmland near Kovilpatti, Thoothukudi district.  Three peahens were discovered in a well, while the carcass of a peacock was located near the well. Authorities rescued another peacock and are investigating the cause of death.

title: Chennai Corporation Tackles Flooding Ahead of Monsoon
news:
The Greater Chennai Corporation (GCC) is undertaking preparatory work to mitigate flooding in the city ahead of the northeast monsoon. Their focus is on three major canals – Otteri Nullah, Virugambakkam Canal and Veernagal Odai – which were recently transferred from the Water Resources Department.

The GCC is prioritizing desilting and plans to conduct a bathymetry survey to assess the silt profile. This data will inform future civil works, including widening the canals by removing encroachments.  Major infrastructure projects, however, will be postponed until after the monsoon.  

The GCC has also deployed machinery to desilt Otteri Nullah and Virugambakkam Canal, with additional measures like installing new shutters and pumping arrangements being considered.  Concerns about sewage pollution in Otteri Nullah have been raised by local residents, who demand further action to address this issue.

title: AIADMK Deputy General Secretary Denies Speculation of Expelled Leaders' Return
news:
K.P. Munusamy, Deputy General Secretary of the AIADMK, has dismissed speculation about the possible return of expelled leaders or a party "unification" effort. Addressing media inquiries about potential reconciliation with former AIADMK leaders Sasikala and O. Panneerselvam before the 2026 elections, Munusamy stated that these discussions are solely a "media construct." 

He emphasized that those expelled were removed due to anti-party activities and attempts to fracture the party. He cited the precedent set by former AIADMK leader Jayalalithaa, where those found guilty were required to submit letters of apology, with the General Secretary deciding their acceptance. 

Munusamy also challenged the Tamil Nadu government's claims of global investment, specifically in Krishnagiri. He pointed out that numerous companies, including Tata Electronics, Ola Electric, and Delta Electronics, were brought to the district during the AIADMK government. He questioned the existence of evidence for claimed global investments in the past four years under Mr. Stalin's leadership.

title: Bengaluru to Experience Power Outage on Thursday
news:

Road, Coles Road and Tannery Road.

title: Tiruppur Corporation Accused of Illegal Waste Dumping
news:
Residents of Pongupalayam, Tiruppur, have accused the Tiruppur City Corporation of illegally dumping solid and liquid waste into abandoned quarries. This practice, according to residents, poses a significant health risk to the surrounding villages of Pongupalayam, Kalampalayam, and Pallipalayam.

The Tamizhaga Vivasayigal Padhukappu Sangam, an organization advocating for farmers' rights, has submitted a representation to the district Collector, Corporation Mayor, Corporation Commissioner, and Pongupalayam panchayat president. They have raised concerns about the potential for epidemics and environmental hazards due to the improper waste disposal. 

The group has also criticized the "shortcomings" in the implementation of the Smart Cities project, specifically regarding waste recycling. They question the rationale behind diverting waste to abandoned quarries instead of implementing more sustainable solutions.

title: Over 800 Academics Condemn Alleged Harassment of Faculty Member at IIMB
news:
Over 800 academics from across the globe, including faculty members from prestigious institutions like IITs and IIMs, have signed an open letter denouncing the alleged harassment of Deepak Malghan by the Indian Institute of Management Bangalore (IIMB). The letter specifically criticizes IIMB's recent demotion of Mr. Malghan, which they call a politically motivated move and a violation of academic freedom.

The letter cites a series of disciplinary actions taken against Mr. Malghan since 2018, which they believe are linked to his advocacy for academic freedom. The academics, including those from renowned institutions like the University of Pennsylvania and Wesleyan University, demand the immediate withdrawal of all sanctions against Mr. Malghan.

In response to the letter, IIMB issued a statement maintaining that disciplinary actions are taken in accordance with established service rules and transparent procedures. They dispute the alleged connection between these actions and Mr. Malghan's advocacy for academic freedom and cite pending legal proceedings as a reason for refraining from further comment.

title: Kejriwal Faces Defamation Trial for Remarks on Modi's Degrees
news:
A Gujarat court has summoned former Delhi Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal and Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) leader Sanjay Singh to face trial in a defamation case. The case stems from alleged "sarcastic" and "derogatory" statements they made regarding Prime Minister Narendra Modi's educational qualifications. 

The Supreme Court on Monday cleared the way for the trial, dismissing Kejriwal's plea to quash the summons. 

The BJP has condemned Kejriwal's comments as "utterly irresponsible" and accused him of "abusing" the Prime Minister. BJP spokesperson Ravi Shankar Prasad highlighted that Kejriwal had previously offered to apologize but was rejected.

The case has sparked political controversy, with BJP criticizing Kejriwal's conduct and drawing parallels to similar situations involving Congress leader Rahul Gandhi. The BJP also dismissed criticism from the opposition regarding an agreement reached between India and China on patrolling the Line of Actual Control.

title: Freo Secures IRDAI License to Offer Specialized Insurance Products
news:
Freo, a digital finance application, has been granted a corporate agent license by the Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority of India (IRDAI). This allows Freo to offer customized insurance products to its 25 million users through partnerships with insurance providers. 

This move aligns with India's "Insurance For All By 2047" goal, aiming to increase insurance penetration in the country, currently at a low 4.2%. Freo's focus will be on cost-effective and intuitive insurance solutions, addressing the common perception of insurance as complex and unnecessary. 

Their offerings will include tailored plans for women's health, supplementary options for existing health policies, and protection against prevalent illnesses like malaria and dengue. 

Freo aims to expand its reach across Tier II and III locations in India, further increasing collaboration with top insurance brands to bring innovative and affordable products to its customers. The company believes this will improve trust, user experience, and grow its customer base.

title: School Students Mistake Narcotics Squad Office for Mechanic's Shop
news:
Three school students from Thrissur, Kerala, accidentally stumbled into the office of the Narcotic Enforcement Squad in Adimaly, Idukki, on Monday. Mistaking the office for a mechanic's shop due to several seized vehicles parked outside, they approached an officer for a matchbox to light their ganja-laced beedis. 

The students, who were on a school trip to Munnar, panicked upon realizing their mistake and attempted to flee. However, officers apprehended them and found five grams of ganja, one gram of hashish oil, and rolling paper in their possession.

Two of the students were booked under the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act and the case was handed over to the Idukki Juvenile Justice Board. The students and their families received counselling sessions and school authorities were instructed to provide follow-up counselling.

title: Former Indian President K.R. Narayanan Honored with Bronze Bust
news:
A bronze bust of Dr. K.R. Narayanan, former President of India, was unveiled at the K.R. Narayanan National Institute of Visual Science and Arts in Thekkumthala, Kerala, on Tuesday, October 22nd, 2024. 

The unveiling was part of the fourth 100-day action plan of the Kerala State government. Higher Education Minister R Bindu presided over the ceremony, with Cooperation Minister V. N. Vasavan in attendance.  K. Radhakrishnan, representing Dr. Narayanan's family, was present with his family. 

The Institute's Chairman, Syed Akhtar Mirza, delivered the welcome speech, and Director Jijoy P.R. offered the vote of thanks.

title: India's National Informatics Centre to Take Over Dharani Portal Maintenance
news:
The Telangana State Government has announced that the National Informatics Centre (NIC) will take over operation and maintenance of the Dharani portal, the state's integrated land records management system, effective December 1st.  This decision follows the expiration of the contract with TerraCIS, a private firm that had been responsible for the portal since its launch in October 2019. 

The NIC, under the Union Ministry of Information Technology, will initially hold the contract for three years, with the possibility of two further extensions based on performance.  This move is intended to address concerns raised by farmers regarding the functioning of the portal and ensure better management of land records for over 70 lakh account holders.

The decision comes after criticism of the previous government's decision to entrust the management of the Dharani portal to a foreign firm.  The Telangana government has expressed that handing the operation over to a public undertaking will better serve the interests of farmers.  A meeting is scheduled for October 25th to finalize the handover process and discuss future application support services for the portal.

title: Kole Wetlands Face Climate Change Threat: Urgent Action Needed
news:
A new study by the Karunya Institute of Technology and Sciences warns of alarming trends threatening the Kole wetlands, designated a Ramsar Site in 2002. The report, commissioned by the Ramsar Bureau-East Asia, identifies escalating urbanisation, rising salinity levels, excessive agrochemical use, mangrove decline, and contamination as key threats.

Urban encroachment has significantly increased in the past two decades, particularly in Puzhakal, Cherpu, and Irinjalakuda.  The study predicts that a sea level rise of 0.5 meters, linked to global warming, could inundate three-quarters of the wetland if preventive measures are not taken. The salinity model identifies Mullesary, Cherpu, and Irinjalakuda as highly vulnerable. 

While crop production is projected to increase slightly by 2030, it is expected to decline significantly by 2060. The study warns that areas with significant mangrove cover, vital for carbon sequestration, will diminish if salinity exceeds 18 ppt in Chetuva and Idianchira. Untreated sewage from Thrissur Corporation and Irinjalakuda Municipality has also compromised water quality in nearby open wells.

The report urges immediate action, including a comprehensive scientific operational policy for the Chimoni reservoir to address irrigation needs. It also emphasizes the urgent need to repair and maintain regulators and barrages at Enamakkal and Idianchira.

Experts stress the importance of planning adaptive measures to mitigate the adverse effects of climate change, developing climate-resilient crop species, and forming regional farmer groups to enhance procurement and marketing of agricultural products. They also advocate for continuous monitoring and an early warning system to safeguard the Kole wetlands, a critical biodiversity hotspot, from further climate change impacts.

title: Bomb Threats Force Security Tightening at Kochi Airport
news:
Two flights departing from Kochi Airport on Tuesday received bomb threats, forcing authorities to increase security measures. An Air India flight bound for London and an Indigo flight en route to Bengaluru were targeted via threats posted on the social media platform 'X'.  

Both flights had already departed by the time the threats were received, after 3 pm. The Indigo flight, which is scheduled to return to Kochi later Tuesday after a stop in Lucknow, will undergo additional security checks upon arrival. 

This incident comes amidst a series of bomb threats received across India, prompting increased security measures at airports nationwide.

title: Karnataka's Caste Census Report: Public Should Know, Says Home Minister
news:
Karnataka's Home Minister G. Parameshwara has stated that the public should be informed about the findings of the socio-economic and educational survey, popularly known as the "caste census," conducted in the state. The survey, commissioned by the previous Congress government in 2015 at a cost of ₹170 crore, was submitted by the Karnataka State Commission for Backward Classes earlier this year. 

Despite objections from some communities, including the Veerashaiva-Lingayat and Vokkaliga communities, who have demanded the report be scrapped, Parameshwara believes the public deserves to know the contents of the report. He clarified that "implementing the report is a different thing," but "people have to be informed as to what is there in the report." 

The report is expected to be discussed at the next Cabinet meeting. While Chief Minister Siddaramaiah has indicated a decision on the report will be taken after considering its pros and cons, the Vokkaligas and Lingayats, who see the survey as "unscientific," are pushing for a fresh survey. 

Conversely, Dalits and OBCs, along with other community leaders, have demanded the report be made public. This issue further complicates the situation, with Deputy Chief Minister D.K. Shivakumar, a Vokkaliga leader, having urged the Chief Minister to reject the report.  The debate over the caste census highlights the complex social dynamics and political sensitivities surrounding caste-based data in Karnataka.

title: Telangana's Economy Stalled After Congress Took Over: KTR
news:
K.T. Rama Rao, working president of the Bharat Rashtra Samithi (BRS), has alleged that Telangana's economy, previously experiencing rapid growth under BRS rule from 2014-15 to 2022-23, has stagnated since the Congress party came to power. He blames the government's policies for this slowdown. 

Rama Rao cited a report in the Economic and Political Weekly, highlighting Telangana's strong financial management during the BRS regime. The state ranked second in debt and resources management indices, demonstrating sound economic practices. 

He further criticized the Congress and BJP for spreading misinformation about the state's financial situation under BRS, stating that their claims of bankruptcy are false. He emphasized the BRS government's effective management of Telangana's finances over its 10-year tenure. 

Rama Rao highlighted the Congress government's decision to send teams to other states to study financial practices as a sign of their incompetence and lack of understanding. He questioned the increase in income for businesses run by Congress leaders' families while the state's revenues have been steadily declining.

title: Youth Arrested for Sexual Assault of Minor in Kalaburagi
news:
A young man from Kalaburagi, Karnataka, has been arrested for allegedly sexually assaulting a minor girl. The incident took place in May 2024 at a tanda (village) in Aland taluk. The accused, identified as Vikas Jadhav, was booked under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012. 

According to the victim's family, Jadhav, who frequently visited his grandmother in the tanda, initially befriended the girl before assaulting her. He reportedly threatened the girl with dire consequences if she revealed the incident to anyone.  The victim's family lodged a complaint with the Narona Police Station, leading to Jadhav's arrest.

title: Southern Railway Cancels Trains Due to Cyclone Dana Warning
news:
The Southern Railway has announced the cancellation of several train services as a precautionary measure due to the impending Cyclone Dana. The Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued a warning for the cyclone, prompting the railway to take action.

The following trains have been cancelled:

title: Reliance Retail May Sell Government's "Bharat" Brand Products
news:
India's government, in a bid to control inflation, is looking to partner with Reliance Retail to distribute its "Bharat" brand flour, rice, and pulses at discounted prices. These products were previously sold through online platforms like Jiomart, Amazon, and Bigbasket.

The government is aiming for a long-term deal with Reliance, hoping to leverage their extensive network of over 18,000 stores across India. This move would make the affordable "Bharat" products accessible to a larger population.

While Reliance has yet to officially comment, the partnership, if finalized, could be a significant step in addressing rising food costs and benefiting consumers across the country. The government is also exploring similar partnerships with other retailers like D-Mart.

title: Doctor Arrested for Illegal Abortion in Kerala
news:
A 68-year-old doctor, Jose Joseph, was arrested in Kollam, Kerala on Tuesday for performing an illegal abortion on an underage girl. Joseph, who runs J.J. Hospital in Krishnapuram, was accused of conducting the procedure without proper records and falsifying the girl's age in the records. 

The police investigation revealed that Joseph had been involved in similar cases in the Kayamkulam and Shaktikulangara police stations. He was previously released on bail in one case with the condition that he would not engage in similar acts. 

The arrest was made by a team led by Kollam Assistant Commissioner of Police M. Sheriff, acting on the instructions of District Police Chief (Kollam City) Chaitra Teresa John.
