title: Karnataka Women's Commission to Address Yadgir Women's Issues
news:
The Chairperson of the Karnataka State Women's Commission, Nagalaxmi Chowdhary, has pledged to address the concerns of women in the Yadgir district. During a visit to the Shorapur Taluk Hospital, Dr. Chowdhary identified issues including inadequate resources at government hospitals, lack of pensions for elderly women, and delays in the Gruha Lakshmi scheme disbursement. She plans to discuss these matters with the Yadgir Deputy Commissioner and work towards solutions. 

Dr. Chowdhary also highlighted the shortage of medical staff at the Taluk Hospital, where only four doctors serve a monthly average of 15,000 outpatients. She intends to advocate for additional staff with the Principal Secretary and Minister of the concerned department.  

Beyond healthcare, Dr. Chowdhary heard from women facing domestic abuse and instructed local officers to investigate these cases and provide protection. Unsolved cases will be reported to the commission.

title: KSCDC Achieves ISO 22000-2018 Certification, Plans for Growth
news:
The Kerala State Cashew Development Corporation (KSCDC) has been awarded the ISO 22000-2018 certification, signifying the company's commitment to maintaining high quality standards in its products. This certification, which is valid for three years, was achieved through a recertification process of their existing ISO 22000-2005 accreditation.

The KSCDC is actively expanding its workforce and has plans to hire 500 additional laborers by January 2025. These new recruits will be focused on the cutting, peeling, and grading sections of the corporation's operations.  The company prioritizes training, offering a month-long program for new hires at their factories. 

The KSCDC's efforts to improve its operations and expand its workforce demonstrate a commitment to remaining competitive and providing high-quality cashew products to the market.

title: Madurai Kamaraj University Holds 56th Convocation, Governor Confers Degrees
news:
Madurai Kamaraj University (MKU) held its 56th annual convocation on Tuesday, with Governor R.N. Ravi conferring degrees on 54,714 graduating students. This included 353 PhD degrees, 1 D.Litt degree, and 26,306 male and 28,408 female graduates. 77 students received endowment prizes and medals for outstanding performance.

Dr. Sudha Seshayyan, Vice-Chairperson of the Central Institute of Classical Tamil, delivered the keynote address. She highlighted the potential dangers of technological advancements, warning that while technology can be a boon, it can also become a tool for oppression and exacerbate social and economic inequalities. 

Dr. Seshayyan also emphasized the importance of human connection and communication in an increasingly digital world, urging students to retain the Indian perspective of knowledge and lifelong learning.

The convocation was met with protest, however. S. Pushparaj, Associate Professor and Head of Department of Econometrics at MKU, boycotted the event, citing the Governor's alleged violation of state traditions and norms. Pushparaj claims that the practice of playing the "Tamil Thai Vaazhthu" (Tamil national anthem) has been changed under the Governor's tenure, played at the end of events instead of the beginning. He also alleges that the Governor has removed certain words from the anthem, further insulting the state.

title: Aavin Keeps Sweet Prices Steady for Deepavali
news:
Despite rising costs for raw materials, Aavin, the Tamil Nadu Cooperative Milk Producers’ Federation, has announced it will not increase prices on its special sweets for Deepavali. This move aims to make the treats accessible to a wider range of consumers. 

Aavin expects to sell ₹120 crore worth of sweets this Deepavali, including popular items like Kaju Katli, Kaju Pista roll, ghee badusha, and nutties halwa. The organization has already begun production at its various units in Salem, Coimbatore, and Erode to ensure timely supply. 

In addition to the sweets, Aavin is also offering ghee, plain khoa, and its popular gulab jamun mix at its outlets. 

While the Tamil Nadu Milk Dealers’ Employees Association welcomes the higher target set by Aavin management, they express concern about the practice of forcing dairy farmers to buy sweets to meet this target. They suggest Aavin implement a more effective marketing strategy.

title: Andhra Pradesh to Promote Cultivation of Trees Used for Traditional Toys
news:
The Andhra Pradesh government has announced plans to promote the cultivation of *Ankudu* and *Tella Poniki* trees, crucial raw materials for the state's iconic Etikoppaka and Kondapalli toys respectively. This initiative will be implemented under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (MGNREGS), focusing on Anakapalle, Alluri Seetharama Raju and NTR districts.

*Ankudu* trees (Wrightia tinctoria) will be cultivated in Anakapalle and Alluri Seetharama Raju districts, while *Tella Poniki* (Jiuotia Rotteri Fromis) will be planted in NTR district. This block plantation program aims to ensure a consistent supply of these unique woods to the toy-making artisans who have been keeping this cultural heritage alive for centuries. 

The initiative will utilize riverbed lands for plantation, with a focus on initial planting on at least 200 acres. The government has issued a circular to district officials to begin implementing the plan, which will involve MGNREGS workers and allocate funds for the project. 

This initiative highlights the government's commitment to preserving traditional crafts and ensuring the sustainability of these unique industries.

title: BJP Extends Membership Drive Deadline to October 30th
news:
The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has extended the deadline for its membership drive to October 30th. This decision was made in anticipation of the upcoming elections in Maharashtra and Jharkhand, as well as by-elections in other states.

According to former MLC N. Ramchander Rao, Telangana has already seen 24 lakh new members join the party, with 9,000 becoming active members by recruiting 100 members each. The party aims to reach 50 lakh members and 40,000 active members in the state by the end of the drive. 

The BJP is also preparing for the election of its state president in Telangana. The process will involve forming booth committees with two active members each, followed by the formation of mandal and district committees. These committees will then elect district presidents, who along with state council members, will form the electoral college to choose the next state president, likely in mid-December. 

The BJP's membership drive extension reflects its efforts to strengthen its base ahead of crucial elections, focusing on active participation and internal democracy within the party.
